Misleading images

Find and avoid misleading images in publications
images
how-to
Author

Helena Jambor

Published

October 9, 2023

I care about science and images that is widely accessible. At present, that is not always the case. Image figures are confusing and unclear. I have extensively written and published on how to make image data understandable. Incomprehensible data is demonstrably less read, less often cited, and unlikely to be included in the scientific canon. Don’t believe me? Letchford et al have data!

Accidentally misleading images

At other times, published images are also misleading, not just unclear. This may be because image data was incorrectly processed. I previously wrote about one case, which illustrated that the sequence of contrast adjustment and image cropping matter! I regularly witness the education gap in my DataViz courses. In the image section the graduate students ask: Is it ok to turn images? Can I crop away a neighbouring cell? Am I allowed to show green fluorescent protein in red? When images are processed without in-depth knowledge of the software, accidentally misleading images may be the result.

Actually misleading images

In comparison more rare are instances of intentional image manipulation. These are cases when authors fabricate or forge data to mislead audiences. Elisabeth Bik has extensively brought attention to this problem and also quantified image manipulations in publications. Already before Biks quantification and activism, early initiatives of scientists and editors clarified what counts as image manipulation and which image processing is acceptable for publication. The CSE guidelines are long and update annually!

Read more

Bik, E.M., Casadevall, A., Fang, F.C., 2016.The Prevalence of Inappropriate Image Duplication in Biomedical Research Publications. mBio 7.

#### Accurate and reproducible image quality Brown, C.M., 2007. Fluorescence microscopy–avoiding the pitfalls.
